The rapid increase of CO2 in the environment is causing severe climate catastrophes and rising ocean surfaces. Therefore, its reduction and green utilization into value-added materials is significant. Herein, heteronuclear bicentric pyridinium-based ionic liquids (BILs) tailored with different chain lengths and halogen anions have been synthesized and structurally characterized. These BILs were utilized as thermally stable, metal-free, and homogeneous catalysts to synthesize other cyclic organic carbonates (COCs) using various epoxides and sustainable, economical, and inert CO2, and their catalytic activity phenomenon has been discussed in detail. The results demonstrated that [TMGH+][ ̶O2MPy+][Br ̶] possesses Lewis acid-base bifunctional characteristics with strong nucleophilic active sites, which play an essential synergistic effect on the activation of CO2 and the ring-opening of epoxides. Various factors affecting the conversion and selectivity of catalysts, including reaction temperature, halide ion, catalyst amount, CO2 pressure, and reaction time, were further investigated. The results illustrated that under metal and solvent-free conditions, the dual functionalized heteronuclear BILs catalyst ([TMGH+][ ̶O2MPy+][Br ̶]) exhibited 99.7 % yield and 99.9 % selectivity at 90 °C temperature and 1 MPa CO2 pressure up to 4 h for the cycloaddition reaction between CO2 and propylene oxide (PO). At the same time, the turn-over frequency was as high as 10.2 h−1. Moreover, the versatility and recyclability of the catalyst were studied, and a plausible reaction mechanism was proposed. Compared to previously reported functionalized heteronuclear bicentric catalysts, [TMGH+][ ̶O2MPy+][Br ̶] requires moderate reaction conditions without using any metal, solvent, or co-catalyst, which demonstrates the bright prospect of synthesizing pyridinium-based bicentric (BILs) catalysts and its practical use in CO2 conversion, activation, and utilization. Graphical abstract Synopsis Novel bicentric dual-functionalized pyridinium-based ionic liquid catalysts were synthesized and utilized for CO2 conversion into cyclic carbonates under moderate conditions. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Bicentric ionic liquids CO2 fixation Cyclic carbonates Cycloaddition reaction Catalysis Data availability The data that has been used is confidential. 1 Introduction The rapid change in global environmental temperature is accredited to a rapid rise in the concentration level of carbon dioxide (CO2) emission in the atmosphere, which has now reached 400 ppm and is causing many environmental problems such as global warming, climate change, and ocean acidification [1,2]. This unprecedented change in the earth atmosphere is primarily due to the ever-expanding energy consumption by humanity, which is a significant threat to global security and health. Reducing the CO2 concentration in the atmosphere has become a global concern [3]. Until now, several techniques have been developed to reduce CO2 levels in the atmosphere, including carbon capture and storage (CCS) and carbon utilization (CCU) and, more importantly, the catalytic conversion of CO2 into value-added products [4]. However, the high thermal stability of CO2 makes its transformation challenging and often requires harsh conditions and high-energy reagents. Because CO2 is non-flammable, inexhaustible, abundant, cheap, and C-1 feedstock for organic synthesis, one of the more convenient ways to reduce its concentration in the atmosphere is to convert it into value-added chemicals such as alkyl formats [5], formic acid [6], cyclic carbonates [7], methanol [8] and so on. The transformation of CO2, especially into cyclic carbonates, is driven by the industrial utilization of various cyclic carbonates as solvents in chemical synthesis, as extracting agents, as essential intermediary products in plastics manufacturing, as solvents for the electrolytes in lithium-ion batteries, as precursors for pharmaceutical intermediates, and as monomers for the polymerization of polycarbonates [9-13]. Synthesis of cyclic carbonates using CO2 and different terminal epoxides as feedstock has been studied in recent years due to 100 % atomic utilization of the reaction in Scheme 1 [14,15]. To date, many catalysts have been developed for this cycloaddition method, such as porous coordination polymers [16,17], metal oxides [18], alkyl borane, and onium iodide [19], porphyrins [20], carboxylic acid compounds [21,22], metal complexes [23,24], metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) [25,26] and quaternary ammonium salt-based catalysts [27]. However, ionic liquids have attracted many researchers over the past few decades because of their tremendous physicochemical properties, such as high polarity, low vapor pressure, environmentally friendly, and high catalytic activity [28,29]. To date, the excellent efficiencies in CO2 conversion have been demonstrated by active-hydrogen ILs [30-32], functionalized poly-ILs [33,34], deep eutectic ionic liquids [35], supported ILs [36], and dual-ILs [37,38]. Several studies have reported that imidazolium-based functionalized ionic liquids are effective catalysts for the cycloaddition of CO2 with epoxides to produce cyclic carbonates. These catalysts demonstrated excellent catalytic efficiency attributed to their unique characteristics including high thermal stability, easy separation from the reaction media, and low viscosity. The physical and chemical properties of the functionalized catalysts can be easily adjusted through structural modification. Various functionalized catalysts demonstrating higher catalytic efficiency have been reported in the literature, including amino, carboxylic, hydroxyl, protic, mono-cation, and di-cation ILs [13,39]. Despite having excellent efficiency in CO2 conversion, most of the developed catalysts still have several limitations, e.g., high cost, prolonged reaction time, complicated catalyst synthesis, difficult separation from reaction media, requiring co-catalyst, and harsh reaction conditions for efficient conversion [40]. Hence, developing a catalytic system that can react with epoxides and CO2 simultaneously and produce cyclic carbonates efficiently is highly desirable as incorporating functional groups, such as hydroxyl and carboxyl groups, has been demonstrated to enhance the catalytic activity by extending the epoxides CO bond, which facilitates a nucleophilic attack [41]. To develop such a catalytic system having both nucleophilic and electrophilic centers, various “bifunctional catalysts” have been synthesized and utilized for the cycloaddition reaction [42,43]. Bicentric ionic liquids (BILs) have two anionic and two cationic parts coupled by an aromatic or aliphatic linker. By changing the linker, anions, and cations in the catalyst structure, the properties of these bicentric ionic liquids, such as chemical stability, solubility, and electrochemical behavior, can be tuned in the same way as mono-centric ionic liquids and such bicentric catalysts (BILs) exhibit high catalytic efficiency due to increased charge density, improved stability, low viscosity, lower catalyst loading, and more active sites in catalyst structure which leads to the simultaneous activation of CO2 and PO. Recently, Hu et al. [43] reported that 1-carboxymethyl-3-methyl- imidazolium bromide [HO2MMIm+][Br−] and 1,1,3,3-tetra-methyl guanidine (TMG) based BILs can produce 84 % PC yield and 0.280 h − 1 TOF by using reaction conditions 0.5 mmol catalyst, 0.1 MPa CO2 pressure, 30 °C temperature and 12 h reaction time. Similarly, Liu et al. [37] synthesized various bifunctional catalysts based on ammonium salts such as [TEOA+O2 ̶][Br ̶][TMGH+], [TEOA+O2 ̶][Br ̶][DBUH+], [TEA+O2 ̶][Br ̶][DBUH+] and [TEA+O2 ̶] [Br ̶][TMGH+] to catalyze the cycloaddition reaction of CO2 and PO and achieved the conversion of 19 %, 28 %, 85 % and 54 % respectively. Still, the harsh reaction conditions (15 mmol catalyst amount, 12 h reaction time, 1.5 Mpa CO2 pressure) were required in this catalytic system for CO2 conversion. Yue et al. [42] achieved a 98.3 % yield of chloroprene carbonate by using amino acid functionalized ionic liquid catalysts to facilitate the cycloaddition reaction of CO2 and epichlorohydrin. However, the reaction requires a high temperature (105 °C) and a long reaction time (13 h). R.B. Mujumdar et al. [43] developed tri-functionalized imidazolium-based ionic liquid catalysts for converting CO2 into cyclic carbonates. The catalysts exhibited high yield and selectivity but required extreme conditions of 120 °C temperature and 2 MPa CO2 pressure. Although there have been a few studies reported on heteronuclear bicentric ionic liquid catalysts, they offer distinct advantages over mono-cationic ionic liquid catalysts, including enhanced stability, catalytic activity, selectivity, and adaptability for catalyst regeneration, as well as the reusability [44]. This work focuses on developing a bifunctional ionic liquid catalytic system, introducing dual anions and cations to achieve high catalytic performance by simultaneously activating CO2 and epoxides. Various halogen ion bicentric ionic liquids catalysts having six-membered pyridine ring structures tailored with carboxylic and amine functional groups have been synthesized, and their catalytic efficiency for the cycloaddition of CO2 with different epoxides has been investigated. The higher catalytic efficiency of these heteronuclear functionalized catalysts is due to the hydrogen-bond donor ability and stronger Brønsted acidity of the carboxylic acid group, which improves the solubility of the catalyst in the reaction mixture. The CO2 is activated through the absorption by the oxygen atom in the carboxylate anion [ ̶O2MPy+], and the epoxide ring is opened through a synergistic effect of hydrogen atoms in [TMGH+], making them superior over mono-centric ionic liquids in terms of more active sites, high yield, excellent selectivity, and high TOF. Moreover, the influence of reaction parameters on the catalytic efficiency, such as catalyst amount, CO2 pressure, reaction temperature, and reaction time, was investigated. The versatility and reusability of the most active catalyst using various epoxides were also examined. Furthermore, the reaction mechanism was thoroughly studied using 1H NMR and FT-IR techniques. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials and methods All commercially available reagents and solvents were used directly without further purification. CO2 as an inexpensive feed-stock was supplied by Beijing Analytical Instrument Factory Ltd. Bromoacetic acid (≥ 98 %), pyridine (≥ 99.5 %), 4-picoline (≥ 98 %), propylene oxide (PO), epichlorohydrin (ECH), butylene oxide (BO), cyclohexene oxide (CHO), styrene oxide (SO), and 1,1,3,3-tetramethylguanidine (TMG) (≥ 99 %) were purchased from Aladdin chemical Co. Ltd. Chloroacetic acid (≥ 98 %) was supplied by Macklin Chemical Co. Ltd., while the solvents used in experiments such as methanol anhydrous (≥ 99 %), ethyl acetate (≥ 99 %) and acetonitrile (≥ 99 %) were purchased from Damao Chemical Co. Ltd. and were used directly to wash the products without further purification. 2.2 Catalyst precursor synthesis The catalyst precursor was successfully synthesized by neutralizing pyridine and haloalkyl acids. Taking ([HO2MPy+][Br ̶] as an example, a solution of (208.34 mmol,15 mL) of bromoacetic acid containing (3 mL, 57.2 mmol) acetonitrile solvent was added dropwise to another solution containing (50 mL, 953 mmol) acetonitrile solvent and (8 mL, 99 mmol) pyridine. The mixture was magnetically stirred for 2 h until a milky precipitate was obtained. The reaction product was washed at least three times with acetonitrile, and the solvent from this milky residue was removed using vacuum filtration. The final product was dried in a vacuum oven at 70 °C for 24 h. Similarly, other catalyst precursors such as 1-carboxymethyl pyridinium chloride [HO2MPy+][Cl̶], 1-carboxtmethyl-4-methylpyridinium chloride [TMGH+][ ̶O2MMPy+][Cl ̶], 1-carboxtmethyl-4-methylpyridinium bromide [TMGH+][ ̶O2MMPy+][Br ̶] were also prepared using same synthetic method. 2.3 Catalyst synthesis The synthesized precursors with different substituents were mixed with 1,1,3,3-tetramethylguanidine (TMG) to synthesize the heteronuclear bicentric ionic liquid catalysts. The general method to synthesize heteronuclear BILs catalysts is demonstrated in scheme 2 . Taking the synthesis of [TMGH+][ ̶O2MPy+][Br ̶] as an example, methanol (20 mL), 1,1,3,3-tetramethylguanidine [TMG] (20 mmol, 1.1518 g) and 1-carboxymethyl pyridinium bromide [ ̶O2MPy+][Br ̶] (20 mmol) were added into a 50 mL round-bottom flask. The flask was kept in a water bath at room temperature, and the mixture was continuously stirred. The neutralization reaction was allowed to proceed for 12 h until a light-brown-colored product was obtained. After completing the neutralization reaction, the solvent was removed from the reaction mixture by rotary evaporator under vacuum at 70 °C, and a light-brown-colored solid with more than 99 % purity was obtained. The final product was washed thrice with methanol to remove impurities and then dried in a vacuum drier for 24 h to remove the moisture. 2.4 Catalytic cycloaddition of epoxide and CO2 The cycloaddition reaction between CO2 and propylene oxide (PO) was carried out in a 25 mL stainless steel autoclave with an automatic temperature control system, pressure sensor, and a magnetic stirrer. In a typical reaction, a mixture of bicentric catalyst amount (0.7 mmol) and propylene oxide (28.6 mmol) was loaded in an autoclave at room temperature. After sealing the autoclave, the air inside the autoclave was replaced with CO2, and pressure was increased to 1 MPa in the absence of any other co-catalyst and solvent. After adding CO2 to the autoclave, the temperature was increased to 90 °C, pressure was continuously increased to 1 MPa, and stirred for 4 h. After reaction completion, the autoclave was placed into the ice water bath and cooled down until it reached ambient temperature. The catalyst was precipitated from the homogenized reaction mixture by diluting it with ethyl acetate solvent and was separated through centrifugal filtration. Gas chromatography (GC) was performed on Agilent 7980A, equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID) and HPI column, to identify the reaction mixture components and their relative concentration in the liquid mixture. At the same time, biphenyl was used as an internal standard for components analysis. The reaction product components and the required products chemical structure were confirmed through the gas chromatography (GC–MS) mass spectrometry characterization technique using (GCMS-QP2020) model. 2.5 Characterization All the synthesized heteronuclear bicentric ionic liquids (BILs) catalysts were analyzed using various characterization techniques such as FT-IR, 1H/13C NMR, TGA, ESI, and Vario EL Cube elemental (C/H/N) analysis. To compare the efficiency of this catalyst, some other catalysts having similar structures, such as [TMGH+][ ̶O2MPy+][Cl ̶], [TMGH+][ ̶O2MMPy+][Br ̶] and [TMGH+][ ̶O2MMPy+][Cl ̶] were also synthesized and their catalytic performance was also explored. The chemical structures of the synthesized bicentric catalysts are demonstrated in scheme 3 . 1-carboxymethyl pyridinium bromide bis(dimethyl amino) methaniminium: 1H NMR (700 MHz, Deuterium Oxide) δ 8.81 ̶8.77 (m, 2H), 8.62 ̶8.58 (m,1H), 8.10 (t, J = 7.0 Hz, 2H), 5.25 (s, 2H), 2.97 (d, J = 1.4 HZ, 12H), 13C NMR (176 MHz, Deuterium Oxide) δ 170.74, 161.35, 145.74, 145.20, 127.85, 63.26 (d, J = 24.1 Hz), 63.06, 38.65. 1-carboxymethylpyridinium chloride bis(dimethyl amino) methaniminium: 1H NMR (700 MHz, Deuterium Oxide) δ 8.78 (d, J = 6.0 Hz, 2H), 8.62 ̶8.52 (m,1H), 8.10 (t, J = 7.0 Hz, 2H), 5.24 (s, 2H), 2.97 (s,12H), 13C NMR (176 MHz, Deuterium Oxide) δ 170.74, 161.35, 145.74, 145.20, 127.85, 63.26 (d, J = 24.1 Hz), 63.06, 38.65. 1-carboxymethyl-4-methylpyridinium chloride bis(dimethyl amino) methaniminium: 1H NMR (700 MHz, Deuterium Oxide) δ 8.67 ̶8.45 (m, 2H), 7.88 (d, J = 6.2 Hz, 2H), 5.14 (s, 2H), 2.96 (s, 12H), 2.67 (s, 3H), 13C NMR (176 MHz, Deuterium Oxide) δ 171.13, 160.30 (d, J = 183.4 Hz), 144.03 (d, J = 22.7 Hz), 128.25 (d, J = 13.9 Hz), 62.46, 38.82, 21.35. 1-carboxymethyl-4-methylpyridinium bromide bis(dimethyl amino) methaniminium: 1H NMR (700 MHz, Deuterium Oxide) δ 8.61 ̶8.45 (m, 2H), 7.89 (d, J = 6.3 Hz, 2H), 5.15 (s, 2H), 2.97 (s, 12H), 2.67 (s, 3H), 13C NMR (176 MHz, Deuterium Oxide) δ 171.14, 160.83 (d, J = 185.5 Hz), 143.92 (d, J = 23.4 Hz), 128.30 (d, J = 13.6 Hz), 47.21, 38.86, 21.37. The chemical composition and the functional groups presence in the catalyst structure were confirmed through an FT-IR spectrometer, where the resolution of 4 cm−1 and 64 transmittance scans were used to cover the spectrum within the wavenumber range of 4000 to 500 cm−1. In contrast, the potassium bromide (KBr) spectrum was used as a reference to confirm the presence of corresponding functional groups. As shown in (Fig. 1 a), FT-IR spectra of all four synthesized BILs illustrates the broad bands around 3430–3350 cm−1, which are assigned to ( ̶NH2) vibrations confirming the formation of amine monomer. The characteristic peaks appeared around 3240–3150 cm−1 and 3080–3030 cm−1 corresponds to O ̶H and C ̶H stretching, while the absorption bands for ̶CC, ̶CO and CN of the pyridine ring appeared at 1680–1557 cm−1. The stretching vibration peaks displaying at 1520 cm−1, 1189 cm−1, and 750–1000 cm−1 correspond to N ̶ O, C ̶ N, and C ̶ C bonds, respectively [45]. The synthesis of dual functionalized pyridinium-based bicentric ionic liquid (BILs) catalysts containing aliphatic and aromatic components coupled with various halide anions was characterized by nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy. The proton 1H NMR for the selected catalyst is shown in (Fig. 1b). The 1H NMR and 13C NMR spectrums were recorded at ambient conditions using Bruker AVANCE III 600 MHZ spectrometer, where deuterated solvent D2O was used to dissolve the catalyst, and tetramethyl silane (TMS) was used as an internal standard. Deuterated solvent D2O (D,99.9 %) was purchased from Cambridge Isotope Laboratories, Inc., and was used directly without further purification. The positive charge on the nitrogen atom in the pyridinium ion reduced the electron density and deshielded the aromatic protons, resulting in aromatic hydrogen peaks between 8.10 ppm and 8.79 ppm. In contrast, the aliphatic hydrogens, ( ̶CH2) group in [ ̶O2MPy+], were deshielded as these were present between two strong electron-withdrawing groups, such as the carboxylic group and pyridinium ion and their peak appears at 5.23 ppm. In comparison, the methyl group ( ̶CH3) peak in [TMGH+] appeared at 2.97 ppm. The carboxylic group hydrogen peak did not occur in 1H NMR due to the proton exchange with D2O. The 1H and 13C NMR spectrums of other synthesized catalysts are demonstrated in (Fig. S2 – S8). The thermal stability of the synthesized catalysts was investigated through thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) using DTG-60H under a nitrogen gas atmosphere. The heating rate was set to increase at 10 °C/min to achieve 600 °C, while the gas flow rate was kept fixed at 30 mL/min. An Alumina pan was used to perform thermogravimetric analysis. The results for the thermal stability of various catalysts are demonstrated in (Fig. 1c). It has been revealed from the TGA profiles that weight loss was only 2.1 ̶ 51.39 % when the temperature was increased from 30 °C to 150 °C under a nitrogen gas atmosphere. This weight loss was due to the presence of hydrogen in the catalyst structure because the presence of hydrogen decreases the thermal stability of the oxygen-containing functional groups [46]. The second weight loss, about 42.7 %, was observed at around 200 °C when the temperature was increased from 200 °C to 600 °C. This weight loss can be attributed to the decomposition of non-volatile compounds, such as amine group ( ̶NH2) decomposition. The results from TGA profiles suggest that the catalyst structure is thermally stable and can be utilized for the catalytic reaction. The molecular weights of the synthesized BILs catalysts were confirmed through ESI mass spectrometry of impact HD (Bruker), where acetonitrile was used as a solvent. Both negative and positive ions modes were used to conduct ESI-MS analysis, and the molecular weight confirmation of the selected catalyst is shown in (Fig. 1d), while the other three synthesized catalysts it is illustrated in (Fig. S11 – S13), respectively. The C/N molar ratios of the synthesized catalysts were determined through elemental analysis and are presented in Table S1. The XPS survey spectrum of [TMGH+][ ̶O2MPy+][Br ̶] catalyst, as presented in (Fig. 2 a), confirms the presence of carbon (C), nitrogen (N), oxygen (O), and bromine (Br) atoms within the catalyst structure. In the detailed analysis of the C 1s spectrum shown in (Fig. 2b), it is further decomposed into three distinct peak regions corresponding to different carbon bonding environments: C ̶C, CN, and CO with a binding energy of 283.89, 286.7, and 290.74 eV respectively [47]. Furthermore, the N 1 s spectrum depicted in (Fig. 2c) reveals two prominent peaks at 398.59 eV and 400.17 eV, which are attributed to the bonding environments of C ̶N and C ̶NH2, respectively, indicating the variety of nitrogen-containing functional groups present in the catalyst structure [48]. The O 1s spectrum is illustrated in (Fig. 2d), revealing a prominent peak at 529.20 eV, attributed to the CO group associated with carboxylic acid. Additionally, the presence of [Br ̶] anion is confirmed through the Br 3d5 spectrum, which exhibits a prominent peak at 66.15 eV [49]. By combining the results of various characterization techniques, it can be confirmed that the catalyst has been successfully synthesized. 3 Results and discussions 3.1 Screening of catalyst To further investigate the effect of catalyst structure on its catalytic efficiency, four catalysts differentiated by their chemical structure were examined to understand their catalytic impact on the cycloaddition reaction. Moreover, the effect of different reaction parameters on the cycloaddition of CO2 and propylene oxide (PO) was explored by a series of reactions using a stainless-steel reactor, and the results are listed in Table 1 . The counterions present in the catalyst structure can affect the polarized properties of the catalyst and the electric structure of the active centers of the catalysts, so their effect on the catalytic efficiency has also been explored. No conversion resulted when a reaction without catalyst addition was carried out (entry 1). The yield of the target product was too low when only a base was used to catalyze the cycloaddition reaction between CO2 and PO (entry 2). A higher yield of 68.3 % in the cycloaddition reaction when acidic pyridinium cation coupled with bromide anion was used as catalyst (entry 3). This confirms that cations and anions have an electrophilic and nucleophilic effect on the ring-opening step of epoxides. Interestingly, the dual-functionalized BILs catalyst [TMGH+][ ̶O2MPy+][Br ̶] demonstrated exceptional results achieving an impressive yield of 75.9 % and selectivity of 99.7 % (entry 4) for the target product, propylene carbonate (PC), in 2 h. The activity of [TMGH+][ ̶O2MPy+][Cl ̶] was also tested, and the yield for the target product was 69.2 % (entry 5), which was lower than entry 4. Meanwhile, the activity of [TMGH+][ ̶O2MMPy+][Cl ̶] was significantly low, with a product yield of 66.7 % (entry 6) compared to the excellent yield of 71.9 % (entry 7) by [TMGH+][ ̶O2MMPy+][Br ̶]. When the reaction time was increased from 2 h to 4 h, there was a significant increase in the yield and selectivity of the target products. As shown in Table 1, the [TMGH+][ ̶O2MPy+][Br ̶] catalyst demonstrated a yield of 85.9 % (entry 8), which is higher than 76.3 % (entry 9). In comparison, the [TMGH+][ ̶O2MMPy+][Br ̶] catalyst also indicates an increasing trend in the catalytic activity over [TMGH+][ ̶O2MMPy+][Cl ̶], showing an excellent yield of 79.8 % (entry 10) compared to 70.5 % (entry 11). The main difference in the catalytic activity is using halide ions, which is crucial for excellent catalytic efficiency. According to Li et al. [50] density functional theory (DFT) study, the ring opening step of the epoxide is a rate-determining step, and a strong nucleophilic anion works more efficiently in the ring opening process than a weaker anion. So, the stronger nucleophilic power of [Br ̶] anion compared to [Cl ̶] anion increases the catalytic conversion rate of the epoxide into the carbonate. It has been reported in previous research [51,52] that halide ions leaving ability and nucleophilicity also determine the catalytic activity of heteronuclear catalysts. Our data shown in Table 1, exhibited higher TOF for Br ̶ ion (15.5 h−1) than Cl ̶ (14.1 h−1) using the same cation structure, following the order of Br ̶ > Cl ̶ as the electron-donating carboxylic ions remove the electronic density from the aromatic ring lowering the LUMO energy of the catalyst, which results in making the proton-donating groups stronger Lewis acids and favoring the interaction of epoxides with active sites of the catalyst. The bromide ions strongly coordinate with the less hindered β ̶C of the epoxides, making it more nucleophilic than the chloride ion due to its lone pair of electrons transfer and establishing a bond with another atom. This high nucleophilic nature of bromide ions leads to higher catalytic activity. From the above discussion, it has been evidenced that the halide ions, [TMGH+], and [ ̶O2MPy+] parts of the dual-IL system can affect the catalytic efficiency of the catalyst. Although, these two catalysts [TMGH+][ ̶O2MPy+][Br ̶] and [TMGH+][ ̶O2MMPy+][Br ̶] have similar structure but their catalytic efficiency is different. The only difference observed between the catalyst structure of [ ̶O2MPy+][Br ̶] and [ ̶O2MMPy+][Br ̶] was that the methyl group was combined with the β-carbon of the [ ̶O2MMPy+][Br ̶], while in the [ ̶O2MPy+][Br ̶], the group was only proton which can also promote the cycloaddition reaction. The catalysts tailored with a methyl group experience greater steric hindrance and low flexibility as methyl groups can also exert electronic effects and influence the reactivity of nearby atoms, which leads to restricting the overall catalytic efficiency of the catalyst [53]. According to previous literature and our findings, it is projected that both the anions and cations in the heteronuclear bicentric ionic liquids catalyst structure play an important role in promoting the cycloaddition reaction of CO2 with epoxides. Based on the DFT study, we propose that bicentric IL catalysts increased catalytic activity due to the combined effects of several factors. The NH bonds of [TMGH+] base cations and N + sites in the pyridine ring contribute positively to the catalytic reaction. Additionally, the halide ion nucleophilically attacks the β-C of the epoxides, further enhancing the catalytic activity [43,54]. The effect of the catalyst amount was examined to screen out the best catalyst for cycloaddition reaction. It can be noted from Table 1, when the amount of catalyst was increased from 0.7 mmol to 1 mmol, the conversion of the target product was also increased with a yield of 86.3 % (entry 12), while the other catalysts have shown a similar increasing trend demonstrating a yield of 77.1 %, 71.9 %, and 81.4 % respectively (entries 13–15). The combined effect of time and pressure on the catalyst performance was also investigated. The results listed in Table 1 demonstrates that when enough reaction time and CO2 pressure were provided to the reaction system, the catalyst demonstrated excellent efficiency with a high yield of 99.7 % and low yield of 96.4 % (entries 16–19). In general, the cycloaddition reaction has been carried out by [TMGH+][ ̶O2MPy+][Br ̶], and this particular catalyst exhibited excellent catalytic efficiency under moderate conditions. 3.2 Influence of reaction parameters The influence of different reaction conditions on the reaction progress was investigated using the best-performing catalyst, and the results are illustrated in (Fig. 3 ). When the reaction temperature was set at 60 °C, the product yield reached only 90.9 %. This may be due to incomplete activation of reactants at this lower temperature resulting in a lower conversion rate [55]. However, increasing the temperature to 90 °C improved the reaction rate, increasing the PC yield from 90.9 % to 99.74 %, as shown in (Fig. 3a). The PC yield gradually increased as the temperature was raised from 90 °C to 100 °C, yielding up to 99.79 %. However, when the temperature of the reaction media was further raised to 120 °C, the product yield did not increase significantly, with a maximum yield of 99.81 % ̶ not considerably different from the yield at 90 °C (99.74 %). Therefore, from the energy conservation perspective, 90 °C was chosen as an optimized reaction temperature for further research. The effect of catalyst amount on the product yield was also studied, as shown in (Fig. 3b). Only 93.5 % PC yield was obtained when low catalyst loading (0.5 mmol) was used in the cycloaddition reaction. When the catalyst amount was increased to 0.7 mmol, a rapid increase in the product yield of up to 99.7 % and high selectivity of up to 99.9 % was noticed, verifying the excellent catalytic performance of the synthesized catalysts. Increasing the amount of catalyst up to 1 mmol does not significantly improve the reaction progress, resulting in only a slight increase in product yield (99.9 %). This suggests that the PO and CO2 did not fully react with the catalyst and did not fully dissolve in the reaction mixture, likely due to an excess of active sites resulting from the high catalyst concentration, which leads to the waste of energy and reduction in the activity of the catalyst [56]. Therefore, 0.7 mmol was chosen as the optimized catalyst loading for the cycloaddition reaction. The effect of CO2 pressure on the cycloaddition reaction is depicted in (Fig. 3c). The CO2 pressure trend shows that only 97.1 % PC yield was achieved when a lower pressure of 0.5 MPa was inserted in the stainless-steel reactor. It can be suggested that CO2 insertion under low pressure (< 0.5 MPa) is a rate-determining step in the reaction, producing a low conversion of epoxides. By increasing the pressure from 0.6 ̶1.0 MPa, the yield increased from 98.3 % to 99.7 %, which explains that more CO2 was soluble in the reaction mixture. However, the selectivity no longer changed at higher pressure (1.5 MPa); the yield reached a maximum of 99.8 %, which has no significant difference from the yield at 1 Mpa (99.7 %), suggesting that CO2 insertion is no longer a rate-determining step. This reaction system has three solid-liquid-gas phases, and the cycloaddition reaction occurs between epoxides and active sites in the liquid phase. The increase in CO2 pressure leads to the epoxides-CO2 interaction in the liquid phase, thus increasing the product yield. However, increased pressure could transfer more epoxides to the gas phase, resulting in a lower concentration of epoxides near the catalyst in the liquid phase, which reduces product yield and decreases the overall efficiency of the catalyst [57,58]. From the experimental results, 1 MPa CO2 pressure was selected as the optimized pressure for further cycloaddition reactions with other epoxides. The effect of reaction time over the CO2 cycloaddition reaction can be explored in (Fig. 3d). When the cycloaddition reaction was allowed only for 1 h, less yield of 78.5 % was achieved for the target product explaining the factor that enough time is required to complete the reaction. When the reaction media was carried out for 2 h, the cycloaddition reaction between PO and CO2 achieved 89.1 % PC yield, significantly higher than 78.5 % (1 h). Interestingly, when the reaction time was increased from 2 h to 4 h, the catalyst exhibited a sharp increase in catalytic efficiency by converting epoxide to a maximum product yield of 99.4 %. When the reaction time was further extended to 5 h, there was no significant change in the PC yield, and the desired product with a high maximum yield (99.6 %) was achieved. So, from the experimental findings, the optimized reaction time for the cycloaddition reaction was chosen as 4 h for further use of the catalyst with other epoxides. Hence, the experimental results suggest that a heteronuclear bicentric ionic liquid (BILs) catalyst can catalyze the cycloaddition reactions efficiently without using other additives under the above-optimized reaction conditions (90 °C, 0.7 mol% catalyst loading, 1 MPa CO2 pressure, and 4 h). Moreover, the PC yield of product and selectivity were 99.7 % and 99.9 %, respectively. 3.3 Comparison of catalytic activity with various catalysts In order to further illustrate the catalytic activity comparison of [TMGH+][ ̶O2MPy+][Br ̶], the results and reaction conditions using various catalysts are summarized in Table 2 . The comparison of catalysts considers multiple factors, including reaction temperature, CO2 pressure, amount of catalyst, reaction time, and TOF. The table shows that all the previously used catalysts can convert CO2 and PO into propylene carbonate (PC) with significant yields and good selectivity. Even though some listed catalysts can conduct the reaction at atmospheric pressure, the only difficulty is requiring a co-catalyst or a solvent to proceed with the reaction as the solvent or co-catalyst is soluble with the product, which leads to difficulty in the product purity and catalyst separation. In addition, using solvents or co-catalysts limits the catalyst's industrial applications and still needs high reaction temperatures or long reaction times due to their low catalytic activity. By comparing the catalytic efficiency of the synthesized catalysts with previously used catalysts, [TMGH+][ ̶O2MPy+][Br ̶] catalyst showed excellent catalytic efficiency and was utilized for the cycloaddition reaction under moderate conditions without adding any solvent or co-catalyst. The results indicate that [TMGH+][ ̶O2MPy+][Br ̶] catalyst has made significant catalytic progress in the epoxide/CO2 coupling reaction. 3.4 Versatility of catalyst over various epoxides To evaluate the catalyst versatility, various epoxides were used in the cycloaddition reaction with CO2, and the results are listed in Table 3 . The catalytic activity of [TMGH+][ ̶O2MPy+][Br ̶] catalyst during the coupling reaction of propylene oxide (PO) and CO2 under the optimized reaction conditions has achieved a product yield of 99.7 % and high selectivity of 99.9 % due to its less steric hindrance (entry 1). This high catalytic activity of the catalyst motivated us to increase the scope of various substrates to see the effect of catalyst efficiency. From the experimental results, it can be seen that all the selected epoxides can be converted efficiently into their respective carbonates in the presence of heteronuclear BILs catalyst, such as 1,2-butylene carbonate, styrene carbonate, and 4-(chloromethyl)-1,3-dioxolan-2-one with yields of 99.2 %, 98.4 % and 98.5 % respectively (entries 2–4). The cyclohexene oxide has shown only 50.5 % yield to the respective cyclic carbonate due to a high steric hindrance caused by internal epoxide in its structure, which made the ring opening very difficult [63]. The results from the Table 3 indicate that [TMGH+][ ̶O2MPy+][Br ̶] is an efficient catalyst that can be used to catalyze various epoxides without using any additives. 3.5 Possible reaction mechanism To understand the reaction mechanism, the cycloaddition reaction was carried out under optimized reaction conditions (90 °C, 1 MPa CO2 pressure, 4 h) and 1H NMR and FT-IR characterization techniques were performed at ambient conditions to investigate the molecular interactions between [TMGH+][ ̶O2MPy+][Br ̶], CO2, and PO, as depicted in (Fig. 4 ). The 1H NMR spectra in (Fig. 4a), both with and without PO, reveal that hydrogen atoms located on C3 and C5 positions of the pyridine ring exhibited a chemical shift moving from 8.49 and 8.68 to 8.51 and 8.70 ppm, respectively. To further explore how hydrogen bonding affects the proton chemical shifts, a study was conducted, as illustrated in (Fig. 4b), where PO interacted with 1,1,3,3-tetramethylguanidine (TMG) base in the presence of CDCl3 deuterated solvent and a downfield peak was observed at 5.19 ppm due to this interaction. According to the literature [64], the formation of hydrogen bonds results in a downfield chemical shift because of the deshielding effect experienced by the hydrogen atom participating in bond formation. This downfield chemical shift pattern aligns with our experimental findings. The 13C NMR spectrum of interaction between PO and TMG can be found in (Fig. S-9) where chemical shifts in 13C peaks were observed from 16.89, 49.19, and 50.32 ppm to 20.81, 62.81, and 77.12 ppm, which corresponds to the carbons atoms located at C1, C2, and C3 position in PO and provides the evidence of interaction between TMG and PO. Upon interaction of the catalyst with CO2 under the optimized reaction conditions, the FT-IR spectrum depicted in (Fig. 4c) revealed a new peak at 1790 cm−1, which was attributed to CO stretching vibration of carbamate (N ̶COO ̶), suggesting the successful activation of CO2 by carboxylic functional group anion. Additionally, a distinct stretch observed at 1142 cm−1 corresponds to C ̶O stretching vibration, further confirming the interaction. To further investigate the hydrogen bonding interaction between the reactive hydrogen atom of the catalyst and PO, the catalyst interacted with PO under optimized conditions without any solvent or co-catalyst. The FT-IR spectrum illustrated in (Fig. 4d) revealed an N ̶H and O ̶H stretching bond vibration at 3424 cm−1 and 3104 cm−1, respectively. Furthermore, a bending vibration of the N ̶H bond was observed at 1647 cm−1, indicating the formation of a hydrogen bond between the oxygen atom of oxiranes and the hydrogen atom of the catalyst. The structure optimization was carried out using the B3LYP method in conjunction with the 6-311G++(d,p) basis set (B3LYP/6-311++G(d,p)). The (Fig. 5 a) illustrates the optimized structure of PO prior to its interaction with TMG, where the bond distance between C ̶O atoms of PO was measured at 1.434 Å. The DFT study revealed that when PO interacted with TMG, the hydrogen bonding between the oxygen atom of PO and the hydrogen atom from the amine group in TMG reduced the bond strength between C ̶O and increased the bond distance from 1.434 Å to 1.441 Å. This bond elongation facilitated the ring-opening process of PO. The bond length of the newly formed hydrogen bond between C ̶O—H is measured at 2.162 Å, as shown in (Fig. 5b). Noncovalent interactions (NCI) significantly affect the catalytic efficiency during chemical reactions. To illustrate the role of hydrogen bonding interactions in the cycloaddition reaction, the cationic part [TMGH+] of the catalyst was subjected to NCI analysis using Multiwfn and Visual molecular dynamics (VMD) [65]. The reduced density gradient (RDG) analysis is depicted in (Fig. 5c), alongside the NCI scatter diagram presented in (Fig. 5d). Based on the FT-IR spectrum, DFT study, and previous experimental studies [66,67], a plausible reaction mechanism for the cycloaddition of CO2 and epoxide using heteronuclear BILs catalysts is depicted in (Fig. 6 ). From the literature [43,44], it has been reported that halide anions and N ̶H bonds from the iminium group can synergistically affect the activation of epoxides where N ̶H active sites act as hydrogen bond donors (HBDs) and activate the epoxides by forming a hydrogen bond with the oxygen atom. This hydrogen bond formation polarizes the C ̶O bond, which activates the epoxide (step 1). In the next step, [Br ̶] anion from the ([ ̶O2MPy+][Br ̶]) catalytic part acts as a strong nucleophile and attacks the less hindered β ̶C atom of the epoxides, which helps to open the epoxides ring by opening the β ̶C ̶O bond. This ring-opening step produces an oxyanion intermediate by forming the β ̶C ̶Br bond (step 2). In the next step, CO2, activated by the electronegative O atom of the carboxylic group, interacts with the highly activated oxyanion intermediate to produce cyclic carbonate compounds, which are stabilized by the intramolecular closed-loop interactions (step 3). Finally, cyclic carbonate is formed via the SN2 mechanism by eliminating the halide anion, which leads to catalyst regeneration (step 4). 3.6 Recyclability effect on catalyst performance A coupling reaction between PO and CO2 was conducted under optimized reaction conditions to explore the impact of recyclability on the catalyst performance. Upon reaction completion, the catalyst was separated from the reaction mixture through centrifugation, and ethyl acetate was utilized to precipitate the catalyst. The recycled catalyst was washed five times with 5 mL of ethyl acetate to remove the impurities and dried under a vacuum at 60 °C for 24 h. The recycled catalyst, after drying, was directly applied to the cycloaddition reaction between PO and CO2 as a model reaction under optimized conditions to check the reusability of the catalyst. The results in (Fig. 7 a) indicate no significant decrease in the catalyst selectivity and conversion after four catalytic recycle runs. This demonstrates that the catalyst exhibited excellent recyclability for the cycloaddition reaction. Later, the recycled catalyst was subjected to FT-IR, TGA analysis and 1H NMR. The FT-IR spectrum of the recycled catalyst, illustrated in (Fig. 7b) did not exhibit any significant changes when compared to the fresh catalyst FT-IR spectrum, indicating that the chemical composition of the catalyst remained unchanged. To investigate the thermal stability of the catalyst, the recycled catalyst underwent thermogravimetric (TGA) analysis. The decomposition profile of the recycled catalyst is depicted in (Fig. 7c), which illustrates that the decomposition temperature of the recycled catalyst remained consistent and did not vary significantly. The 1H NMR spectrum shown in (Fig. 7d) demonstrates that the catalyst structure was stable and no significant change was observed after four recycles. 4 Conclusion A series of easily prepared novel dual-functionalized heteronuclear bicentric ionic liquid (BILs) catalysts with multiple active sites were synthesized, and their structures were characterized. The heteronuclear bicentric functionalized catalysts with pyridine ring were utilized as an efficient and inexpensive catalyst to convert inert CO2 into cyclic carbonates under moderate reaction conditions (90 °C, 1 MPa CO2 pressure, 4 h). The dual functionalized BILs catalysts possess structural features such as thermal stability, more active sites, and hydrogen-bond donor (HBD) groups. It was inferred from the findings that the presence of halide ions in the catalyst structure has a significant role in determining the catalyst's activity. From the previous research and our findings, it has been concluded that when the polarizability of halogen ions increases, the selectivity of the catalyst also increases. Through the optimization of reaction conditions, [TMGH+][ ̶O2mPy+][Br ̶] was selected as an excellent dual-functionalized BILs catalyst for the cycloaddition of CO2 and epoxides into respective cyclic carbonates. Moreover, the catalyst demonstrates excellent structural stability; it can be easily separated and recycled at least four times without enough deactivation. The catalyst can also be utilized to convert several other substrates. The synthesized dual-functionalized BILs catalytic system is anticipated to synergize the cycloaddition of CO2 into cyclic carbonates. coredata.dc:description: The rapid increase of CO2 in the environment is causing severe climate catastrophes and rising ocean surfaces. Therefore, its reduction and green utilization into value-added materials is significant. Herein, heteronuclear bicentric pyridinium-based ionic liquids (BILs) tailored with different chain lengths and halogen anions have been synthesized and structurally characterized. These BILs were utilized as thermally stable, metal-free, and homogeneous catalysts to synthesize other cyclic organic carbonates (COCs) using various epoxides and sustainable, economical, and inert CO2, and their catalytic activity phenomenon has been discussed in detail. The results demonstrated that [TMGH+][ ̶O2MPy+][Br ̶] possesses Lewis acid-base bifunctional characteristics with strong nucleophilic active sites, which play an essential synergistic effect on the activation of CO2 and the ring-opening of epoxides. Various factors affecting the conversion and selectivity of catalysts, including reaction temperature, halide ion, catalyst amount, CO2 pressure, and reaction time, were further investigated. The results illustrated that under metal and solvent-free conditions, the dual functionalized heteronuclear BILs catalyst ([TMGH+][ ̶O2MPy+][Br ̶]) exhibited 99.7 % yield and 99.9 % selectivity at 90 °C temperature and 1 MPa CO2 pressure up to 4 h for the cycloaddition reaction between CO2 and propylene oxide (PO). At the same time, the turn-over frequency was as high as 10.2 h−1. Moreover, the versatility and recyclability of the catalyst were studied, and a plausible reaction mechanism was proposed. Compared to previously reported functionalized heteronuclear bicentric catalysts, [TMGH+][ ̶O2MPy+][Br ̶] requires moderate reaction conditions without using any metal, solvent, or co-catalyst, which demonstrates the bright prospect of synthesizing pyridinium-based bicentric (BILs) catalysts and its practical use in CO2 conversion, activation, and utilization.
